drupalNodeEvent.title: At a Crossroads: China's Post-Pandemic Economic Relations with Latin America and the Caribbean

field_speakers.processed:
• Margaret Myers: Director, Asia and Latin America Program, Inter-American Dialogue
  • Rebecca Ray: Senior Academic Researcher, Boston University Global Development Policy Center
  • Ignacio Tornero: Founder and CEO, East Consulting
  • Fermin Koop (Moderator): Editor, Diálogo Chino

field_organizers.processed: Boston University Global Development Policy Center and the Inter-American Dialogue.

field_description.processed:
According to the International Monetary Fund, Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) is experiencing continued low economic growth amid a stalling COVID-19 recovery, rampant inflation, and the knock-on effects of Russia’s war in Ukraine. China, too, is facing economic uncertainties, even as growth is expected to markedly increase this year. Amid these difficulties, China-LAC deal-making continues more or less apace, however—often related to the shifting economic realities brought about by climate change and energy transformation.

On Wednesday, May 24, 9:00-10:00 AM EDT, join the Boston University Global Development Policy Center and the Inter-American Dialogue for a virtual discussion of China's evolving economic relations with LAC, featuring new findings and data. What trends were evident in China-LAC economic engagement in 2022? How are China-LAC trade, investment, development finance, debt, and diplomacy evolving amid shifting economic demands and new policy agendas? And what are the prospects for future China-LAC engagement across economic sectors?
